moves.4. cxd5 Qxd5: It appears that Nenarokov has the advantage, as he has 3 developed pieces to Alekhine's one.
moves.7. Bd2 Bxf3: Forcing Alekhine's hand, as PxN would now be answered with BxP, leaving Black a pawn up.
moves.8. exf3 Nb4: Electing to press forward. N-K4 might have been a safer alternative.
moves.9. a3 Nxd5: A mistake that Alekhine exploits at once.
moves.10. Na4: The Queen has no flight square! Nenarokov resigns at once. [This game repeated itself in 1957, Tolush vs. Aronson. Chess games have repeated before -- one time with same player as the victim! Akiba Rubinstein fell into an opening trap -- identical moves -- twice in 2 years: for details see "The Fireside Book of Chess".]
